{{multiple issues| {{self-published|date=September 2012}} {{Original research|date=September 2012}} {{technical|date=August 2015}} }} {{Infobox organization | name = The Humble Guys | image = | formation = 1980s | origin = | headquarters = None (digital group) | category = [[warez]] | num_staff = | website = }} '''The Humble Guys''' ('''THG''') were a [[software cracking|cracking]] group for the [[IBM PC]] during the late 1980s founded by two friends known by the [[pseudonym]]s Candyman and Fabulous Furlough. The group was also noticed in the [[demoscene]] for some of their [[cracktro]]s.
THG was the first group to make use of the [[.nfo|NFO]] file as a means for [[documentation|documenting]] their releases before packaging and distribution.<ref>http://pdf.textfiles.com/academics/online-software-piracy-of-the-last-millennium-1_0.pdf</ref> The first release to contain an .NFO file was Nova Logic's remake of the [[arcade game|arcade classic]] [[Bubble Bobble]] in 1989. This has since spawned an entire generation of [[ASCII art]]ists devoted solely to creating [[art]]work for the purpose of decorating NFO files for [[warez]] groups. To put things into perspective, there are now entire websites explicitly devoted to the collection and archival of NFO files, such as [[The iSONEWS]].
{{TOC left}}
==Software contributions== [[Image:READTHG - The Humble Thug cracktro.png|right|thumb|320px|Screenshot from the THG [[cracktro]] <tt>READTHG.EXE</tt> featuring ''The Humble Thug''.]] THG also was one of the first groups to release an "intro tool" for the [[IBM]] [[Personal computer|PC]] [[demoscene]], released by their coding subsidiary, ''THG F/X'', called the THG IntroMaker. The THG IntroMaker would allow one to create a self-contained executable program which played music and displayed graphics on screen without the need for any knowledge of [[computer programming]]. A much more advanced and highly sophisticated extension of this today would be [[Farbrausch]]'s ''.werkkzeug''.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=tXBdOoZ-faYC&pg=PA36&dq=werkkzeug</ref>
Prior to THG's arrival on the [[warez scene]] the IBM world did not have anything other than text based intros usually quoting song lyrics. THG members brought the experience from the C64 and AMIGA warez scene bringing the first animated and graphical intros to the IBM scene.
In December 1991 , the "F/X division" of The Humble Guys released a first and only copy of an [[diskmag|electronic magazine]] called "The Humble Review" featuring game reviews and articles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/the-humble-review |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402004738/http://www.defacto2.net/organisation/the-humble-review |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-04-02 |title=The Humble Review |publisher=Defacto2 |date= |accessdate=2012-09-17 }}</ref><!-- This is a non-controversial claim for which a self published source is acceptable --> Writer and weblogger [[Justin Hall]] would have his first article published in the Humble Review; a film review of [[Akira (1988 film)|Akira]] by "Fusty".
Members of THG also had their own custom [[bulletin board system|BBS]] software, originally a "forum hack", called L.S.D. BBS (Lush Software Designs) which was first introduced on June 1, 1990, written by The Slavelord and others. The original source code for this was Emulex/2, which was acquired by a THG member who's alias was Tripin Face. The source code was referred to as 'Jani' in some communities at the time. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://software.bbsdocumentary.com/IBM/DOS/LSDBBS/ |title=The BBS Software Directory |publisher=Software.bbsdocumentary.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-17}}</ref>
==In the news== On the evening of October 27, 1992, [[NBC]] [[television]] aired an episode about [[computer]] [[Hacker (computer security)|hackers]] on [[Dateline NBC|Dateline]] titled "''Are Your Secrets Safe?''".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.totse.com/en/zines/cud_a/cud454.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-02-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050212002627/http://www.totse.com/en/zines/cud_a/cud454.html |archivedate=2005-02-12 |df= }}</ref> This show prominently displayed [[advertising|ads]] for several warez BBSes, including one for The Slave Den BBS which was operated by a senior member and spokesperson of THG. As a result of this undesired exposure, The Slavelord voluntarily retired from his activities within the group.<ref>http://www.textfiles.com/piracy/i_retire.txt</ref>
On September 5, 2006, David J. Francis, known by his username "Candyman" died in his hometown of St. Louis Missouri, of heart failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/STLToday/DeathNotices.asp?Page=LifeStory&PersonID=19145167 |title=David J. Francis Obituary: View David Francis's Obituary by St. Louis Post-Dispatch |publisher=Legacy.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-17}}</ref>
On October 4th, 2015, Pierre Barkett, known by his username "The PieMaN" died in Florida of heart failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/timesunion/obituary.aspx?n=PIERRE-BARKETT&pid=176039492}}}</ref>
==Competition== <!--[[Image:PITSACD2 ANS.png|right|width|240px|ANSI art advertisement for The Pits BBS.]]-->
THG redefined the manner in which the PC Warez Scene worked when they entered the scene in 1989. Prior to THG, warez releases were haphazard, with multiple groups releasing the same title, usually after the title had been available in retail stores for weeks. Often games were released to BBSes without being cracked. THG changed this by releasing titles days before the software made it to retail chains such as [[GameStop|Babbage's]]. They did this by establishing relationships with the major wholesale software distributors, and ordering games with overnight shipping. For those cases where overnight shipping wasn't enough, THG found people who lived near the software companies, who could go to the company, and buy the game the day it was released. This beat the overnight shipping method by 2 days in most cases. Also, an advantage that they possessed was that most other warez groups were run by teens, who attended school during the day. THG was run by professional men, who were available each day "by 10:30" when FedEx, or UPS delivered. The other groups had to "wait until they got home" in the afternoons. A decided advantage considering most "cracks" were done in less than an hour, and releases complete shortly thereafter.
THG had members who worked for morning TV shows. Software companies, ever eager for free advertising, would send a box of new, or in some cases "about to be released" software to a TV show, for just a simple phone call. They also understood the "progression" of software. Once a title was completed, the box, manual, and final version of the game, were shipped to a "duplication house" to copy the software for sale in stores. THG had contacts in these duplication houses, where they could get the games weeks before they would show up at the store. Activision's F-14 Tomcat was one such title, along with all titles from Microprose.
At the height of their power, THG had game suppliers in the US, UK, France, Germany, and many parts of Asia.
THG introduced the concept of couriers in an effort to plaster their releases on their competitors' BBSes. The THG couriers were often told to make sure that the various groups received the latest crack on their HQ's BBS before other THG BBSes. The combination of using software wholesalers and couriers turned the PC Warez Scene upside down in 1990, but these are considered normal practice now. The fierce competition within the current warez and video scenes are directly descended from THG.
As a result of the fierce competition from THG, the majority of older, well established, warez groups disappeared from the scene.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} Of the four or five groups that were around prior to THG's arrival in December, 1989, the only group that survived the onslaught from THG was the [[International Network of Crackers]] (INC).
One of THG's greatest competitors in the IBM PC cracking scene was the [[International Network of Crackers]] (INC). The file header of the [[executable]] THG cracktro, <tt>READTHG.EXE</tt> (displayed above), contains text which reads: "''Cool Hand [[anal sex|but fuck]]s his dog and Phantom from INC''" ([[sic]]), an insulting reference towards the vice-president and courier coordinator of their rival organization, INC.
After Candyman shut down his BBS (Candyland - originally run on CNET BBS and ''first setup and up by The Bandit (this is untrue)'', setup, development and maintenance was continued by The Maker including unique customization, who was on hand from day one, for Candyman.) After Candyman left the United States, Fabulous Furlough took over the reins of the group. After political infighting among the remaining members of the group led to problems within the organization, several of the newer members of THG splintered off and formed a new group called USA ([[United Software Association]]) which included several noteworthy members such as Genesis and The Humble Babe (who changed her name to The NotSoHumble Babe upon her departure from THG). USA released a few games, most of them coming from one of THG's suppliers in Illinois, whom USA had managed to "turn". After the bust of The Not So Humble Babe on credit card fraud charges in Michigan, USA teamed up the European PC warez division of [[Fairlight (group)|Fairlight]] and were cooperatively known as "USA/FLT". This inevitably lead to the two groups USA and THG warring with each other.<ref>[http://www.defacto2.net/file/detail/a73d55 ]{{dead link|date=September 2012}}</ref>
A year after the USA/FLT fiasco, several of the original members of The Humble Guys left the group in an effort to once again capture lightning in a bottle. However, by the fall of 1992 several other groups, such as [[Razor 1911]] had joined the scene and this new group, while having some brief success,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.textfiles.com/piracy/NFO/term2029.nfo |title=Terminator 2029 - Yes, that's right! Term 2029! |publisher=Originally Funny Guys |date= |accessdate=2012-09-17}}{{Self-published source|date=September 2012}}</ref> was never as successful as THG. The new group fell apart shortly after The Slavelord shut down his BBS after the Dateline story.
During 1992 though early 1994, many THG releases were supplied by the UK branch which compromised mostly of Hi.T.Moonweed, Bryn Rogers and Hydro who struggled to keep the group together due to US burnout. The UK BBS's, The Flying Teapot and The Demons Forge (ran by Hi.T and Bryn respectively) became the UK's major landmarks.
By 1994, most of the founding members of The Humble Guys were no longer involved with the warez scene, and the group was just a shadow of its former self. After the Pits BBS in New York was shut down by [[Novell]] in 1995,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novell.com/news/press/archive/1995/11/pr95259.html |title=Novell Software Piracy Investigation Leads to Court- Ordered Shut Down of Pits Bulletin Board System |publisher=Novell.com |date=1995-11-06 |accessdate=2012-09-17}}</ref> the group moved to IRC (Internet Relay Chat) and had a presence on many different servers with the name #THG. They focused on distribution rather than cracking. The Humble Guys disbanded in the early 2000s when the last founding member left.

{{Orphan|date=August 2017}}
{{italic title}} '''''The Medieval Underworld''''' is a 1972 illustrated book authored by Andrew McCall,<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Medieval Underworld|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=kn5LHQAACAAJ|publisher = Sutton Publishing|date = 2004-07-22|isbn = 9780750937276|first = Andrew|last = McCall}}</ref> published by [[Barnes & Noble Books]] in [[New York City|New York]]. It details the basis for criminal and ecclesiastical justice from the fall of Rome to about 1500.
The book has been distinguished in [[Mark Galeotti]]'s ''Paths of Wickedness and Crimes''<ref>{{Cite book|title = Paths of Wickedness and Crime|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=cevjAwAAQBAJ|publisher = Lulu.com|date = 2012-01-01|isbn = 9781300097440|first = Mark|last = Galeotti}}</ref> for its discussion of organized crime in medieval Europe, and it forms part of the basis of the [[Institute of Economic Affairs|IEA]]'s overview course on Crime and Society.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.iea.org.uk/sites/default/files/Crime%20and%20Society.pdf|title = Crime and Society, Course Syllabus|date = Aug 30, 2015|accessdate = Aug 30, 2015|website = Institute of Economic Affairs|publisher = Institute of Economic Affairs|last = |first = }}</ref>
In popular culture, ''The Medieval Underworld'' has been suggested as a source of primary material for role-playing game developers.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Shared Fantasy: Role Playing Games as Social Worlds|url = https://books.google.com.pe/books?id=EGBJ-3rwRWwC&printsec=frontcover&vq=%2522The+Medieval+Underworld%2522&source=gbs_citations_module_r&cad=2#v=onepage&q=%2522The%2520Medieval%2520Underworld%2522&f=false|publisher = University of Chicago Press|date = 2002-08-14|isbn = 9780226249445|first = Gary Alan|last = Fine}}</ref>

Ed. 2d]] 835 |Docket=12-696 |OralArgument=https://www.oyez.org/cases/2010-2019/2013/2013_12_696 |OpinionAnnouncement=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/13pdf/12-696_4f57.pdf |Prior=''Galloway v. Town of Greece'', 732 [[F. Supp. 2d]] [https://www.leagle.com/decision/infdco20100806960 195] ([[W.D.N.Y.]] 2010); reversed, 681 [[F.3d]] [https://www.leagle.com/decision/infco20120517106 20] ([[2d Cir.]] 2012); [[Certiorari|cert]]. granted, {{ussc|569|993|2013|el=no}}. |Subsequent= |Holding= The town of Greece does not violate the First Amendment's Establishment Clause by opening its meetings with sectarian<ref name="WP20140505">{{cite news|title=Supreme Court approves sectarian prayer at public meetings|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/religion/supreme-court-approves-sectarian-prayer-at-public-meetings/2014/05/05/62c494da-d487-11e3-8f7d-7786660fff7c_story.html|accessdate=May 8, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 5, 2014|author=Lauren Markoe And Cathy Lynn Grossman}}</ref> prayer that comports with America's tradition and doesn't [[Coercion test|coerce]] participation by nonadherents. The judgment of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit|Second Circuit]] is reversed. |SCOTUS=2010-2016 |Majority=Kennedy (except as to part II-B) |JoinMajority=Roberts, Alito (in full); Scalia, Thomas (except as to part II-B) |Concurrence=Alito |JoinConcurrence=Scalia |Concurrence2=Thomas (in part and in judgment) |JoinConcurrence2=Scalia (as to part II) |Dissent=Breyer |JoinDissent= |Dissent2=Kagan |JoinDissent2=Ginsburg, Breyer, Sotomayor |LawsApplied=[[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|U.S. Const. amend. I]] }}
'''''Town of Greece v. Galloway''''', 572 U.S. ___ (2014), is a [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] case in which the court decided that the [[Town of Greece]], New York may permit volunteer chaplains to open each legislative session with a prayer.<ref>{{ussc|name=Town of Greece v. Galloway|volume=572|year=2014|docket=12-696}}.</ref><ref name="NYT20140505">{{cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|title=Town Meetings Can Have Prayer, Justices Decide|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/06/nyregion/supreme-court-allows-prayers-at-town-meetings.html?hp|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 5, 2014|accessdate=May 5, 2014}}</ref> The plaintiffs were Susan Galloway and Linda Stephens, represented by [[Americans United for Separation of Church and State]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Stohr|first=Greg|title=‘Let Us Pray’ Before Town Council Becomes High Court Case|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-26/let-us-pray-before-town-council-begins-is-high-court-case.html|accessdate=10 October 2013|newspaper=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=26 July 2013}}</ref> They argue that the prayers violate the [[Establishment Clause]] of the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] ruled against the town,<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Galloway v. Town of Greece |vol=681 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=20 |pinpoint= |court=[[2d Cir.]] |date=2012 |url=https://www.leagle.com/decision/infco20120517106 |accessdate=2018-11-15 |quote=}}</ref> and on May 20, 2013 the Supreme Court agreed to rule on the issue.<ref>{{cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|title=Justices Take Case on Prayer at Town Board Meetings, and a Patent Dispute|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/21/us/politics/justices-take-case-on-prayer-at-town-board-meetings.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=10 October 2013|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=20 May 2013}}</ref> On May 5, 2014, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of the Town of Greece, and that the town's practice of beginning legislative sessions with prayers does not violate the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment.<ref>{{cite news|last=Adler|first=Jonathan H.|title=Breaking — Supreme Court upholds legislative prayer in Town of Greece v. Galloway|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/05/05/breaking-supreme-court-upholds-legislative-prayer-in-town-of-greece-v-galloway/|accessdate=May 6, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 6, 2014}}</ref>
==Question before the court== Does the town of Greece, New York, impose an impermissible establishment of religion by opening its monthly board meetings with a prayer?
==Decision of the court==
===Majority opinion===
By a 5-4 vote, the Court ruled that the town's practice did not violate the Establishment Clause. The majority opinion authored by Justice Kennedy stated: "The town of Greece does not violate the First Amendment by opening its meetings with prayer that comports with our tradition and does not coerce participation by nonadherents."<ref>[https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/13pdf/12-696_4f57.pdf Opinion of the Court, page 24.]</ref> The court concluded that the town's practice of opening its town board meetings with a prayer offered by members of the clergy does not violate the Establishment Clause when the practice is consistent with the tradition long followed by Congress and state legislatures, the town does not discriminate against minority faiths in determining who may offer a prayer, and the prayer does not [[Coercion test|coerce]] participation with non-adherents.<ref name="Howe20140505">{{cite web|last=Howe|first=Amy|title=Tradition! Today’s legislative prayer decision in Plain English|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2014/05/tradition-todays-legislative-prayer-decision-in-plain-english/|publisher=SCOTUSblog|accessdate=May 8, 2014|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Walsh20140405">{{cite web|last=Walsh|first=Mark|title=A "view" from the Court: A divided ruling on prayer, but no fireworks|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2014/05/a-view-from-the-court-a-divided-ruling-on-prayer-but-no-fireworks/|publisher=SCOTUSblog|accessdate=May 8, 2014|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Denniston20140505 ">{{cite web|last=Denniston|first=Lyle|title=Opinion analysis: Prayers get a new blessing|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2014/05/opinion-analysis-prayers-get-a-new-blessing/|publisher=SCOTUSblog|accessdate=May 8, 2014|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref>
The majority held that sectarian prayers at government meetings are permissible under the Constitution.<ref name="WP20140505" /><ref name="NYT20140505" /> “To hold that invocations must be non-sectarian would force the legislatures sponsoring prayers and the courts deciding these cases to act as supervisors and censors of religious speech,” Kennedy wrote for himself and the conservative members on the court.<ref name="WP20140505" /> Lawmakers and judges would otherwise have to police prayer, he wrote, involving “government in religious matters to a far greater degree than is the case under the town’s current practice of neither editing nor approving prayers in advance nor criticizing their content after the fact.”<ref name="WP20140505" /> This means that prayers are allowed to invoke particular religious affiliations without running afoul of the First Amendment prohibition against endorsement of religion at federal, state or local level.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kaufmann|first=Scott|title=Florida town’s choice: Violate Supreme Court ruling or open meeting with Satanic prayer|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2014/05/09/florida-towns-choice-violate-supreme-court-ruling-or-open-meeting-with-satanic-prayer/|accessdate=May 11, 2014|newspaper=The Raw Story|date=May 9, 2014}}</ref>
Kennedy stated that U.S. Constitution doesn't require the town of Greece to search outside the town for chaplains from other faiths as long as the town maintains a policy of nondiscrimination. He however included a restraint on legislature prayers by stating that "[t]he purpose of legislative prayer is to lend gravity” to sessions where “the divisive business of governing” will take place.<ref name="Walsh20140405" /> Noting that legislature prayer (in this context) should be “solemn and respectful in tone”,<ref name="Howe20140505" /> Kennedy went on to state that when legislative prayers are used as an opportunity to condemn or try to convert people who are not members of a particular religion, then these prayers would not conform with the Constitution.<ref name="Howe20140505" /> He added in general: "Absent a pattern of prayers that over time denigrate, proselytize, or betray an impermissible government purpose, a challenge based solely on the content of a particular prayer will not likely establish a constitutional violation."<ref>[https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/13pdf/12-696_4f57.pdf Syllabus opinion, p. 3]</ref>
Justice Kennedy wrote: “Legislative bodies do not engage in impermissible coercion merely by exposing constituents to prayer they would rather not hear and in which they need not participate.”<ref name="NYT20140505" /> According to the majority legislative prayers might be impermissible if they “denigrate nonbelievers or religious minorities, threaten damnation, or preach conversion,” or if the prayer giver is chosen in a religiously discriminatory way.<ref name="WPVolokh20140505">{{cite news|last=Volokh|first=Eugene|title=The Supreme Court’s city council prayer decision|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/05/05/the-supreme-courts-city-council-prayer-decision/|accessdate=May 8, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref>
===Concurring opinions=== Justice Thomas wrote in his separate opinion (which was joined in part by Justice Scalia) that the case should be dismissed because the Establishment Clause doesn't apply to the states and its subdivisions, but only to Congress. He also stated that the Constitution would have only been violated if “actual legal coercion” like imposing taxes to pay for the church is used.<ref name="Howe20140505" /><ref name="WP20140505Adler" /> Justice Alito wrote a separate concurring opinion (which was joined in part by Justice Scalia) in which he dealt with points raised by Justice Kagan in her dissent.<ref name="Howe20140505" /><ref name="WP20140505Adler" /> In Alito's view “the logical thrust of many of [Justice Kagan's] arguments is that prayer is never permissible prior to meetings of [[Local government in the United States|local government]] legislative bodies.”<ref name="WP20140505Adler">{{cite news|last=Adler|first=Jonathan H.|title=Breaking — Supreme Court upholds legislative prayer in Town of Greece v. Galloway|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/05/05/breaking-supreme-court-upholds-legislative-prayer-in-town-of-greece-v-galloway/?tid=up_next|accessdate=May 8, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref>
===Dissenting opinions===
Justice Breyer filed a dissent that focused on the case facts<ref name="Howe20140505" /> and argued that the town must do more to make its legislative prayer inclusive of other faiths.<ref>{{cite web|title=Town of Greece v. Galloway|url=https://www.oyez.org/cases/2010-2019/2013/2013_12_696|work=The Oyez Project at IIT Chicago-Kent College of Law|publisher=The Oyez Project at IIT Chicago-Kent College of Law|accessdate=May 9, 2014}}</ref>
The main dissent was authored by Justice Kagan<ref>{{cite news|last=Feldman|first=Noah|title=Justice Kennedy has us all in his prayers|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/opinion/justice-kennedy-has-us-all-in-his-prayers/article_f95abade-d327-5f07-b390-999cf4d97d5d.html|accessdate=May 19, 2014|newspaper=The St.Louis Post-Dispatch|date=May 5, 2014}}</ref> and it was joined by Justices Ginsburg, Breyer and Sotomayor.<ref name="Howe20140505" /> Kagan noted three key differences between the case before the court and ''[[Marsh v. Chambers|Marsh]]'' (1983):<ref name="Howe20140505" /> # The Greece Town Council is not only a legislature, but also a place where the local government interacts with the local residents. # The prayers in Greece were not directed to lawmakers, but instead also to the local residents seeking to do business with the government. # The prayers in Greece were sectarian in nature. Noting these differences, Kagan wrote: "So month in and month out for over a decade, prayers steeped in only one faith, addressed toward members of the public, commenced meetings to discuss local affairs and distribute government benefits. In my view, that practice does not square with the First Amendment’s promise that every citizen, irrespective of her religion, owns an equal share in her government."<ref name="WP20140505Adler" /> According to Kagan the providing equal treatment would have been easy: town council members could tell the chaplains that the prayers should be non-denominational, or they could have invited clergy from all different faiths to give the prayers, rather than focusing almost exclusively on Christian ministers.<ref name="WPVolokh20140505" /><ref name="WP20140505Adler" /> However, the town didn’t employ either of those measures.<ref name="WP20140505Adler" />
==Reaction to ruling== The reactions to the court's ruling were diverse. Christian conservatives and others who feel that religious expression has been overly curtailed in public settings were happy with the ruling. Eric Rassbach, deputy general counsel of the Becket Fund for Religious Liberty, called the court's decision "a great victory for religious liberty."<ref name="WP20140505" /> Along with their supporters, the Jewish and atheist women who filed suit against the town of Greece were disappointed by the court's ruling.<ref name="WP20140505" /> A number of Jewish organizations, including the [[American Jewish Committee]] and the [[Anti-Defamation League]], had filed [[amici curiae]] briefs in support of the respondents, and expressed disappointment with the majority's decision.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jewish groups pan US Supreme Court prayer ruling Read more: Jewish groups pan US Supreme Court prayer ruling|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/jewish-groups-pan-us-supreme-court-prayer-ruling/|accessdate=9 May 2014|newspaper=The Times of Israel|date=7 May 2014}}</ref> Secular groups were also disappointed. Daniel Mach, director of the ACLU Program on Freedom of Religion and Belief, for example stated: “We are disappointed by today’s decision. Official religious favoritism should be off-limits under the Constitution. Town-sponsored sectarian prayer violates the basic rule requiring the government to stay neutral on matters of faith.”<ref name="WP20140505" /> Ira Lupu, a law professor emeritus at George Washington University who specializes in the First Amendment, called the court's ruling "a very bad decision" because it undermined the Establishment Clause. Lupu explained that the court decision "does not insist on any [...] reasonable effort to make prayer nonsectarian or to push for diversity. The majority faith in a particular community can dictate the prayers and minority faiths could be left out if they don’t step up and say, ‘Hey, what about us?'"<ref name="WP20140505" />
The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' pointed out that the decision divided the justices along religious lines, as well as ideological ones. All five justices in the majority were Catholics, and three out of the four dissenters were Jewish.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-supreme-court-religion-catholics-jews-20140505-story.html |title=Prayer case divides Supreme Court justices along religious lines |author=David G. Savage |publisher=''Los Angeles Times'' |date=2014-05-05 |accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref>
==Constitutional prescription for legislative prayers== According to [[Lyle Denniston]] the constitutional prescription for legislative prayers is based on eight factors. These factors are:<ref name="Denniston20140505" />
# Legislative prayers are not confined to meetings of Congress or state legislatures, but may also be recited in the more intimate and familiar setting of local government meetings. # The prayer portion of the meeting must be conducted only during a ceremonial part of the government body’s session, not mixed in with action on official policy. # The body may invite anyone in the community to give a prayer and (if it has the money) could have a paid chaplain. The officials on the body may also join in the prayer by bowing their heads or showing other signs of religious devotion, such as crossing themselves. # The body may not dictate what is in the prayers and what may not be in the prayers. A prayer may invoke the deity or deities of a given faith, and need not embrace the beliefs of multiple or all faiths. # In allowing “sectarian” prayers, the body’s members may not “proselytize” i.e. promoting one faith as the true faith, and may not require persons of different faith preferences, or of no faith, to take part, and may not criticize them if they do not take part. # The “sectarian” prayers may not disparage or discriminate against a specific faith, but officials need not go to extra lengths to make sure that all faiths do get represented in the prayer sessions — even if that means one faith winds up as the dominant message. # Such prayers are permissible when most, if not all, of the audience is made up of adults. # A court, in hearing a challenge to a prayer practice, is confined to examining “a pattern of prayers,” and does not have the authority to second-guess the content of individual prayer utterances. In judging such a pattern, the proper test is not whether it tends to put forth predominantly the beliefs of one faith, but whether it has the effect of coercing individuals who do not share that faith.
==See also== * ''[[Marsh v. Chambers]]'': holding that the practice of hiring a chaplain for the Nebraska state legislature did not violate the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment * ''[[Mouvement laïque québécois v Saguenay (City)]]'': a similar Canadian case

{{Infobox protocol | name = Z-Wave | image = Z-Wave logo.jpg | caption = | standard = 800-900 MHz radio frequency range | developer = Zensys | introdate = {{Start date|2001}} | industry = Home automation | connector = <!--connector(s) usable with protocol--> | hardware = <!--examples of compatible hardware--> | range = 100 meters | newer = <!--superseded by which protocol--> }}
'''Z-Wave''' is a [[wireless]] communications protocol used primarily for [[home automation]]. It is a [[mesh networking|mesh network]] using low-energy radio waves to communicate from appliance to appliance,<ref>Harold Stark, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/haroldstark/2017/05/22/the-ultimate-guide-to-building-your-own-smart-home-in-2017/#37992e4c3afb "The Ultimate Guide To Building Your Own Smart Home In 2017,"] ''[[Forbes]]'', May 22, 2017.</ref> allowing for wireless control of residential appliances and other devices, such as lighting control, security systems, thermostats, windows, locks, swimming pools and garage door openers.<ref name="okaven">Oliver Kaven, [https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,1749559,00.asp "Zensys' Z-Wave Technology,"] ''[[PC Magazine]]'', January 8, 2005.</ref><ref name="lfrenzel">Lou Frenzel, [http://www.electronicdesign.com/communications/what-s-difference-between-zigbee-and-z-wave "What's The Difference Between ZigBee And Z-Wave?"] ''Electronic Design'', March 29, 2012.</ref> Like other protocols and systems aimed at the home and office automation market, a Z-Wave automation system can be controlled from a wireless [[keyfob]], a wall-mounted keypad or through smartphones, tablets or computers, with a Z-Wave gateway or central control device serving as both the hub controller and portal to the outside.<ref name="okaven"/><ref name=digitaltrends031216>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/home/smarten-dumb-house-z-wave-automation/|title=Smarten up your dumb house with Z-Wave automation|website=Digital Trends|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref> It provides interoperability between home control systems of different manufacturers that are a part of its alliance. There are a growing number of interoperable Z-Wave products; over 1,700 in 2017,<ref name="rpink">Roger Pink, [http://electronics360.globalspec.com/article/8625/zigbee-vs-z-wave-for-the-iot "ZigBee vs Z-Wave for the IoT,"] Electronics 360, May 4, 2017.</ref> and over 2,400 by 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.silabs.com/2018-04-18-Silicon-Labs-Completes-Acquisition-of-Sigma-Designs-Z-Wave-Business|title=Silicon Labs Completes Acquisition of Sigma Designs' Z-Wave Business|work=Silicon Labs|access-date=2018-04-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
==History== The Z-Wave protocol was developed by Zensys, a Danish company based in [[Copenhagen]], in 2001.<ref name="awestervelt">Amy Westervelt, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/amywestervelt/2012/03/21/could-smart-homes-keep-people-healthy/#73991a0b579a "Could Smart Homes Keep People Healthy?"] ''Forbes'', March 21, 2012.</ref><ref name="dehrlich">David Ehrlich, [https://gigaom.com/2008/12/18/sigma-designs-buying-smart-network-chipmaker-zensys/ "Sigma Designs Buying Smart Network Chipmaker Zensys,"] [[GigaOm]], December 18, 2008.</ref> That year, Zensys introduced a consumer light-control system, which evolved into Z-Wave as a proprietary [[system on a chip]] (SoC) home automation protocol on an unlicensed frequency band in the 900 MHz range.<ref name="ohersent">Olivier Hersent, David Boswarthick and Omar Elloumi, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=yGRW-6tlHRAC&pg=PT186&lpg=PT186&dq=Zensys+Z-Wave&source=bl&ots=3S7AYCXASk&sig=rqmHJ8cxMl7byl5UOfN3cCG0xQU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjv4dWYgITUAhVi5YMKHXLxAzQ4FBDoAQg2MAQ#v=onepage&q=Zensys%20Z-Wave&f=false The Internet of Things: Key Applications and Protocols]'', West Sussex: [[John Wiley & Sons]], chapter 8, 2012.</ref> Its 100 series chip set was released in 2003, and its 200 series was released in May 2005,<ref name="okaven"/> with the ZW0201 chip offering a high performance at a low cost.<ref name="pmannion">Patrick Mannion, [http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1161000 "Intel funds Z-Wave developer Zensys,"] ''[[EE Times]]'', May 1, 2006.</ref> Its 500 series chip, also known as Z-Wave Plus, was released in March 2013, with four times the memory, improved wireless range, and improved battery life.<ref>Michael Brown, [http://www.techhive.com/article/2031180/sigma-designs-announces-next-gen-z-wave-home-control-product-family.html "Sigma Designs announces next-gen Z-Wave home-control product family,"] TechHive, March 19, 2013.</ref> The technology began to catch on in North America around 2005, when five companies, including [[Danfoss]], [[Ingersoll-Rand]] and [[Leviton|Leviton Manufacturing]], adopted Z-Wave.<ref name="dehrlich"/> They formed the Z-Wave Alliance, whose objective is to promote the use of Z-Wave technology, with all products by companies in the alliance interoperable.<ref name="awestervelt"/><ref name="dehrlich"/> In 2005, [[Bessemer Venture Partners]] led a $16 million third seed round for Zensys.<ref name="dehrlich"/> In May 2006, [[Intel Capital]] announced that it was investing in Zensys, a few days after Intel joined the Z-Wave Alliance.<ref name="pmannion"/> In 2008, Zensys received investments from [[Panasonic]], [[Cisco Systems]], [[Palamon Capital Partners]] and Sunstone Capital.<ref name="dehrlich"/>
Z-Wave was acquired by [[Sigma Designs]] in December 2008.<ref name="dehrlich"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hometech.fm/shows/151|title=Episode 151 - Discussing Z-Wave with Executive Director Mitch Klein|work=HomeTech.fm|access-date=2017-03-07|language=en-US}}</ref> Following the acquisition, Z-Wave's US headquarters in [[Fremont, California]] were merged with Sigma's headquarters in [[Milpitas, California]].<ref name="dehrlich"/><ref>Kevin J. O'Brien, [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/06/technology/06iht-srifa06.html "Home of the Future Still Years Away,"] ''[[New York Times]]'', September 5, 2012.</ref> On January 23, 2018, Sigma announced it planned to sell its Z-Wave business to [[Silicon Labs]] for $240m,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sigmadesigns.com/news/sigma-designs-inc-announces-plan-sell-z-wave-business-240-million/|title=Sigma Designs, Inc. Announces Plan to Sell its Z-Wave Business for $240 Million {{!}} Sigma Designs|work=Sigma Designs|access-date=2018-03-27|language=en-US}}</ref> which was completed on April 18, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.silabs.com/2018-04-18-Silicon-Labs-Completes-Acquisition-of-Sigma-Designs-Z-Wave-Business|title=Silicon Labs Completes Acquisition of Sigma Designs' Z-Wave Business|work=Silicon Labs|access-date=2018-04-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2005, six products on the market used Z-Wave technology. By 2012, as smart home technology was becoming increasingly popular, there were approximately 600 products using Z-Wave technology available in the US.<ref name="awestervelt"/> By May 2017, over 1,700 products have been certified by the Z-Wave Alliance.<ref name="rpink"/> As of April 18, 2018, there were over 2,400 interoperable Z-Wave products.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.silabs.com/2018-04-18-Silicon-Labs-Completes-Acquisition-of-Sigma-Designs-Z-Wave-Business|title=Silicon Labs Completes Acquisition of Sigma Designs' Z-Wave Business|work=Silicon Labs|access-date=2018-04-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Interoperability== Z-Wave's interoperability layer ensures that devices can share information and allows all Z-Wave hardware and software to work together. Its wireless mesh networking technology enables any node to talk to adjacent nodes directly or indirectly, controlling any additional nodes. Nodes that are within range communicate directly with one another. If they aren’t within range, they can link with another node that is within range of both to access and exchange information.<ref name="lfrenzel"/> In September 2016, certain parts of the Z-Wave technology were made publicly available, when Sigma Designs released a public version of Z-Wave's interoperability layer, with the software added to Z-Wave's open-source library. The open-source availability allows software developers to integrate Z-Wave into devices with fewer restrictions. Z-Wave's S2 security, Z/IP for transporting Z-Wave signals over IP networks, and Z-Ware middleware are all open source as of 2016.<ref name="jmorra">James Morra, [http://www.electronicdesign.com/iot/z-wave-specifications-go-open-source "Z-Wave Specifications Go Open-Source,"] ''Electronic Design'', September 7, 2016.</ref>
==Standards and the Z-Wave Alliance== The Z-Wave Alliance was established in 2005 as a consortium of companies that make connected appliances controlled through apps on smartphones, tablets or computers using Z-Wave wireless mesh networking technology. The alliance is a formal association focussed on both the expansion of Z-Wave and the continued interoperability of any device that utilises Z-Wave.<ref name=digitaltrends031216/><ref name="awestervelt"/><ref>Brian X. Chen, [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/12/technology/smartphones-can-now-run-consumers-lives.html "Smartphones Become Life's Remote Control,"] ''New York Times'', January 11, 2013.</ref>
In October, 2013, Sigma Designs and the Z-Wave Alliance announced a new protocol and interoperability certification program called Z-Wave Plus, based upon new features and higher interoperability standards bundled together and required for the 500 series [[system on a chip]] (SoC), and including some features that had been available since 2012 for the 300/400 series SoCs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://z-wavealliance.org/sigma-designs-z-wave-alliance-introduce-new-z-wave-plus-certification-program/|title=Sigma Designs and Z-Wave Alliance Introduce New Z-Wave Plus™ Certification Program - Z-Wave Alliance|date=22 October 2013|publisher=}}</ref> In February 2014, the first product was certified by Z-Wave Plus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://products.z-wavealliance.org/products/953|title=Leak Gopher Z-Wave Valve Controller|publisher=}}</ref> The alliance aims to create for the smart home a secure mesh network that works across different platforms.<ref name="lhamilton">Laura Hamilton, [https://www.cedmagazine.com/news/2016/12/z-wave-alliance-announces-board-member-and-new-security-mandate "Z-Wave Alliance Announces Board Member and New Security Mandate,"] ''CED Magazine'', December 22, 2016.</ref>
Z-Wave is designed to achieve reliable communication and operation between devices and sensor-enabled objects from various manufacturers in the Z-Wave Alliance, which consists of over 450 members.<ref name="rpink"/> Members of the alliance include Intermatic, [[Leviton]], Techniku, [[Carrier Corporation|Carrier]], [[ADT Corporation]], FAKRO, [[Ingersoll Rand]], Jasco, [[LG Uplus]], Nortek Security & Control, [[Sigma Designs]], [[SmartThings]], [[Honeywell]], [[Robert Bosch GmbH|Bosch]], [[Belkin]], Zipato, August Home and [[Black & Decker]].<ref name="okaven"/><ref name=digitaltrends031216/><ref name="jmorra"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://z-wavealliance.org/z-wave_alliance_member_companies/|title=Member Companies of the Z-Wave Alliance - Z-Wave Alliance|website=Z-Wave Alliance|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref><ref>Eric Abent, [https://www.slashgear.com/august-home-joins-z-wave-alliance-for-smart-lock-pro-04480791/ "August Home joins Z-Wave Alliance for Smart Lock Pro,"] Slash Gear, April 4, 2017.</ref>
==Technical characteristics== === Radio frequencies === Z-Wave is designed to provide reliable, low-latency transmission of small data packets at data rates up to 100kbit/s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://z-wavealliance.org/about_z-wave_technology/ |title=About Z-Wave Technology |date=March 2013 |accessdate=2013-05-13}}</ref> The throughput is 40kbit/s (9.6kbit/s using old chips) and suitable for control and sensor applications,<ref name="eetimes1"/> unlike [[Wi-Fi]] and other [[IEEE 802.11]]-based [[wireless LAN]] systems that are designed primarily for high data rates. Communication distance between two nodes is about 30 meters (40 meters with 500 series chip), and with message ability to hop up to four times between nodes, it gives enough coverage for most residential houses. [[Modulation]] is by [[Manchester code|Manchester channel encoding]].<ref name="eetimes1">{{cite web|url=http://www.embedded.com/design/connectivity/4025721/Catching-the-Z-Wave|title=Catching the Z-Wave | Embedded|date=2006-10-02|publisher=embedded.com|author=Mikhail T. Galeev|accessdate=2015-07-26}}</ref>
Z-Wave uses the Part 15 unlicensed industrial, scientific, and medical ([[ISM band|ISM]]) band.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sigmadesigns.com/zwave_frequency_coverage.php|title=Z-Wave : Home control|last=Online|first=Sigma Designs|website=www.sigmadesigns.com|access-date=2016-03-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717060540/http://www.sigmadesigns.com/zwave_frequency_coverage.php|archivedate=2014-07-17|df=}}</ref> It operates at 868.42 MHz in Europe, at 908.42 MHz in the North America and uses other frequencies in other countries depending on their regulations.<ref name="lfrenzel"/> This band competes with some [[cordless telephone]]s and other consumer electronics devices, but avoids interference with [[Wi-Fi]], [[Bluetooth]] and other systems that operate on the crowded {{nowrap|[[ISM band|2.4 GHz]]}} band.<ref name=digitaltrends031216>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/home/smarten-dumb-house-z-wave-automation/|title=Smarten up your dumb house with Z-Wave automation|website=Digital Trends|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref> The lower layers, MAC and PHY, are described by [[ITU-T]] G.9959 and fully backwards compatible. In 2012, the [[International Telecommunication Union]] (ITU) included the Z-Wave PHY and MAC layers as an option in its G.9959 standard for wireless devices under 1 GHz. Data rates include 9600 bps and 40 kbps, with output power at 1 mW or 0 dBm.<ref name="lfrenzel"/> The Z-Wave transceiver chips are supplied by Sigma Designs and [[Mitsumi]].

===Network setup, topology and routing=== Z-Wave uses a [[source routing|source-routed]] [[Mesh networking|mesh network]] architecture. Mesh networks are also known as '''[[wireless ad hoc network]]s'''. In such networks, devices use the wireless channel to send control messages which are then relayed by neighboring devices in a wave-like fashion. The source device wanting to transmit is therefore known as the initiator. Hence, the name source-initiated mesh ad hoc routing. There were several source-initiated mesh routing protocols proposed in the period early 1990s. The earlier ones were [[Associativity-Based Routing]] (ABR)<ref>{{cite journal|first=Chai-Keong |last=Toh |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1008812928561|title=Associativity-Based Routing for Ad Hoc Mobile Networks |journal=Wireless Personal Communications |date=March 1997 |volume=4 |issue=2 |p=103–139 |access-date=March 19, 2018}}</ref> and [[Dynamic Source Routing]] (DSR).<ref>{{cite web|url= https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4728 |title=RFC 4728: The Dynamic Source Routing Protocol (DSR) for Mobile Ad Hoc Networks for IPv4 | date=February 2007 |publisher=[[IETF]] | author=Johnson, D. |author2=Y. Hu |author3=D. Maltz |access-date=March 19, 2018}}</ref>.
Devices can communicate to one another by using intermediate nodes to actively route around and circumvent household obstacles or radio dead spots that might occur in the [[multipath propagation|multipath]] environment of a house.<ref name="eetimes1"/> A message from node A to node C can be successfully delivered even if the two nodes are not within range, providing that a third node B can communicate with nodes A and C. If the preferred route is unavailable, the message originator will attempt other routes until a path is found to the C node. Therefore, a Z-Wave network can span much farther than the radio range of a single unit; however, with several of these hops a slight delay may be introduced between the control command and the desired result.<ref>{{cite web|last=Loughlin|first=Thomas|title=Z-Wave Christmas Lights|url=http://thomasloughlin.com/z-wave-christmas-lights/|publisher=Thomas Loughlin|accessdate=3 December 2012|quote=Any further and I would see a slow down in the control of any device on the network. We did get it to work at about 130 feet but it took about 3 minutes for the device to get the on/off message.}}</ref>
The simplest network is a single controllable device and a primary controller. Additional devices can be added at any time, as can secondary controllers, including traditional hand-held controllers, key-fob controllers, wall-switch controllers and PC applications designed for management and control of a Z-Wave network. A Z-Wave network can consist of up to 232 devices, with the option of [[Bridging (networking)|bridging]] networks if more devices are required.<ref name="lfrenzel"/>
A device must be "included" to the Z-Wave network before it can be controlled via Z-Wave. This process (also known as "pairing" and "adding") is usually achieved by pressing a sequence of buttons on the controller and on the device being added to the network. This sequence only needs to be performed once, after which the device is always recognized by the controller. Devices can be removed from the Z-Wave network by a similar process. The controller learns the signal strength between the devices during the inclusion process, thus the architecture expects the devices to be in their intended final location before they are added to the system. Typically, the controller has a small internal [[battery backup]], allowing it to be unplugged temporarily and taken to the location of a new device for pairing. The controller is then returned to its normal location and reconnected.
Each Z-Wave network is identified by a Network ID, and each device is further identified by a Node ID. The Network ID (also called Home ID) is the common identification of all nodes belonging to one logical Z-Wave network. The Network ID has a length of 4 bytes (32 bits) and is assigned to each device, by the primary controller, when the device is "included" into the Network. Nodes with different Network IDs cannot communicate with each other. The Node ID is the address of a single node in the network. The Node ID has a length of 1 byte (8 bits) and must be unique in its network.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vesternet.com/understanding-z-wave-networks |title=Understanding Z-Wave Networks, Nodes & Devices |publisher=Vesternet.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121213015518/http://www.vesternet.com/understanding-z-wave-networks |archivedate=2012-12-13 |df= }}</ref>
The Z-Wave chip is optimized for battery-powered devices, and most of the time remains in a power saving mode to consume less energy, waking up only to perform its function.<ref name="ohersent"/> With Z-Wave mesh networks, each device in the house bounces wireless signals around the house, which results in low power consumption, allowing devices work for years without needing to replace batteries.<ref name="jmorra"/> For Z-Wave units to be able to route unsolicited messages, they cannot be in sleep mode. Therefore, battery-operated devices are not designed as repeater units. Mobile devices, such as remote controls, are also excluded since Z-Wave assumes that all repeater capable devices in the network remain in their original detected position.
===Security=== Z-Wave is based on a proprietary design, with Sigma Designs as its primary chip vendor.<ref name="lfrenzel"/> In 2014, Mitsumi became a licensed second source for Z-Wave 500 series chips.<ref>[http://www.sigmadesigns.com/news/z-wave-becomes-multi-sourced-standard-as-home-control-market-heats-up-globally/ "Z-Wave Becomes Multi-Sourced Standard as Home Control Market Heats Up Globally,"] sigmadesigns.com, January 2, 2014.</ref> Although there have been a number of academic and practical security researches on home automation systems based on [[Zigbee]] and [[X10 (industry standard)|X10]] protocols, research is still in its infancy to analyze the Z-Wave protocol stack layers, requiring the design of a radio packet capture device and related software to intercept Z-Wave communications.<ref name="sensep"/><ref name="scapy-radio">{{cite web |url= https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-14/materials/us-14-Picod-Bringing-Software-Defined-Radio-To-The-Penetration-Testing-Community-WP.pdf |title= Bringing Software Defined Radio to the Penetration Testing Community |publisher= BlackHat USA |date= 2014 |first1= Jean-Michel |last1= Picod |first2= Arnaud |last2= Lebrun |first3= Jonathan-Christofer |last3= Demay }}</ref> An early vulnerability was uncovered in AES-encrypted Z-Wave door locks that could be remotely exploited to unlock doors without the knowledge of the encryption keys, and due to the changed keys, subsequent network messages, as in "door is open", would be ignored by the established controller of the network. The vulnerability was not due to a flaw in the Z-Wave protocol specification but was an implementation error by the door-lock manufacturer.<ref name="sensep">{{cite web |url= https://sensepost.com/cms/resources/conferences/2013/bh_zwave/Security%20Evaluation%20of%20Z-Wave_WP.pdf |title= Security Evaluation of the Z-Wave Wireless Protocol |publisher= Sense Post |date= 2013 |first1= Behrang |last1= Fouladi |first2=Sahand |last2=Ghanoun}}</ref>
On November 17, 2016, the Z-Wave Alliance announced stronger security standards for devices receiving Z-Wave Certification as of April 2, 2017. Known as Security 2 (or S2), it provides advanced security for smart home devices, gateways and hubs.<ref name="lhamilton"/><ref>William Wong, [http://www.electronicdesign.com/communications/qa-s2-s-impact-z-wave-and-iot-security "Q&A: S2's Impact on Z-Wave and IoT Security,"] ''Electronic Design'', January 17, 2017.</ref> It shores up encryption standards for transmissions between nodes, and mandates new pairing procedures for each device, with unique PIN or [[QR codes]] on each device. The new layer of authentication is intended to prevent hackers from taking control of unsecured or poorly-secured devices.<ref>Ry Crist, [https://www.cnet.com/news/z-wave-smart-home-gadgets-announce-new-iot-security-standards/ "Z-Wave smart-home gadgets announce new IoT security standards,"] [[CNET]], November 17, 2016.</ref><ref>Ry Crist, [https://www.cnet.com/news/your-z-wave-smart-home-gadgets-just-got-more-secure/ "Your Z-Wave smart home gadgets just got more secure,"] CNET, April 3, 2017.</ref> According to the Z-Wave Alliance, the new security standard is the most advanced security available on the market for smart home devices and controllers, gateways and hubs.<ref>Ken Briodagh, [http://www.iotevolutionworld.com/smart-home/articles/430956-mandatory-security-implementation-z-wave-iot-devices-takes.htm "Mandatory Security Implementation for Z-Wave IoT Devices Takes Effect,"] IoT Evolution, April 4, 2017.</ref>
=== Hardware === The chip for Z-Wave nodes is the ZW0500, built around an [[Intel MCS-51]] [[microcontroller]] with an internal system clock of 32 MHz. The RF part of the chip contains an [[GFSK|GisFSK]] transceiver for a software selectable frequency. With a power supply of 2.2-3.6 volts, it consumes 23mA in transmit mode.<ref name="eetimes1"/> Its features include AES-128 encryption, a 100kbps wireless channel, concurrent listening on multiple channels, and USB VCP support.<ref>[http://aeotec.com/z-wave-500-series-module-chip "Z-Wave 500 series,"] Aeotc.com. Accessed July 30, 2017.</ref>
===Comparison to other protocols=== For smart-home wireless networking, there are numerous technologies competing to become the standard of choice. [[Wi-Fi]] consumes a lot of power, and [[Bluetooth]] is limited in signal range and number of devices. Other network standards competing with Z-Wave include [[Insteon]], [[Thread (network protocol)|Thread]] and [[ZigBee]]. Of the three, Z-Wave has the longest open-air operating range at 300 feet (outdoor) and 80+ feet (indoor). Insteon has the largest number of maximum devices capability at 17.7 million (to ZigBee's 65,000 and Z-Wave's 232). Thread has the fastest data transmission rate at 250 kbps. Z-Wave has better interoperability than ZigBee, but ZigBee has a faster data transmission rate. Thread operates on the busy Wi-Fi standard frequency of 2.4 GHz, while Z-Wave operates at 908 MHz in the US, which has reduced noise and a greater coverage area. ZigBee operates on both 915 MHz and 2.4 GHz frequencies. All three are mesh networks.<ref>Kevin Parrish, [http://www.tomsguide.com/us/smart-home-wireless-network-primer,news-21085.html "ZigBee, Z-Wave, Thread and WeMo: What's the Difference?"] Tom's Guide, July 14, 2015.</ref><ref name="blewis">Brandon Lewis, [http://embedded-computing.com/articles/z-wave-opens-up-as-smart-home-connectivity-battle-closes-in/ "Z-Wave opens up as smart home connectivity battle closes in,"] Embedded Computing Design, September 2, 2016.</ref> The Z-Wave MAC/PHY is globally standardized by the International Telecommunications Union as ITU 9959 radio, and the Z-Wave Interoperability, Security (S2), Middleware and Z-Wave over IP specifications were all released into the public domain in 2016, making Z-Wave highly accessible to Internet of Things developers.<ref name="blewis"/>
